question_text:
A group of 92 students is going on a rafting trip. If each raft holds 4 students, how many rafts will the students need?


__ rafts
solution: Rafts needed = Total number of students ÷ Number of students each raft holds. So, divide the number of students by the number in each raft.
solution_image_tag: Long division showing 92 ÷ 4 = 23. The complete calculation displays the quotient 23 above the division bracket, with the work shown: 9 ÷ 4 = 2 remainder 1, bring down 2 to make 12, then 12 ÷ 4 = 3 with no remainder.

question_text:
There are 63 Dragon Ball Z warriors training in groups. If each training group holds 3 warriors, How many training groups are needed?


__ training groups
solution: Training groups needed = Total number of warriors ÷ Number of warriors each training group holds. So, divide the number of warriors by the number in each training group.
The warriors will need 21 training groups.
solution_image_tag: Long division showing 63 ÷ 3 = 21. The complete calculation displays the quotient 21 above the division bracket, with the work shown: 6 ÷ 3 = 2 remainder 0, bring down 3 to make 3, then 3 ÷ 3 = 1 with no remainder.

__ vans
solution: Vans needed = Total number of fans ÷ Number of fans each van holds. So, divide the number of fans by the number in each van.
solution_image_tag: Long division showing 88 ÷ 8 = 11. The complete calculation displays the quotient 11 above the division bracket, with the work shown: 8 ÷ 8 = 1 remainder 0, bring down 8 to make 8, then 8 ÷ 8 = 1 with no remainder.

__ houses
solution: Houses needed = Total number of students ÷ Number of students each house holds. So, divide the number of houses by the number in each house.
